items.text: I feel most alive when I'm painting, writing, or composing music.
items.rationale: Direct expression of engagement with core artistic activities—visual art, writing, and music composition.

items.text: I need the freedom to express myself without rigid rules or structure.
items.rationale: Preference for unstructured, expressive environments is a hallmark of the Artistic type.

items.text: People describe me as imaginative and unconventional.
items.rationale: Third-person observation capturing the creativity and nonconformity central to the Artistic type.

items.text: I am drawn to work that allows me to create something original and beautiful.
items.rationale: Valuing originality and aesthetic creation is a core Artistic motivation.

items.text: I would rather design something unique than follow a proven template.
items.rationale: Preference for novelty over convention clearly distinguishes the Artistic orientation.

items.text: I regularly attend art exhibitions, theater performances, or poetry readings.
items.rationale: Behavioral indicator of active engagement with artistic and cultural experiences.

items.text: I often lose track of time when I'm working on a creative project.
items.rationale: Flow states during creative work are characteristic of the Artistic personality.

items.text: Aesthetic beauty in my surroundings matters deeply to me.
items.rationale: High aesthetic sensitivity is a defining trait of the Artistic type.

items.text: I find conventional 9-to-5 office jobs stifling and uninspiring.
items.rationale: Aversion to conventional, structured work environments is typical of Artistic individuals.

items.text: I enjoy experimenting with different artistic media like photography, sculpture, or digital design.
items.rationale: Exploration across multiple creative media reflects broad Artistic interests.

items.text: I use music, art, or writing as a way to process my emotions.
items.rationale: Using creative outlets for emotional expression is a core Artistic behavior.

items.text: I value self-expression more than financial security in my career choices.
items.rationale: Prioritizing expression over material reward is a strong Artistic value orientation.

items.text: I often daydream about stories, images, or melodies that I want to bring to life.
items.rationale: Daydreaming about creative content is Artistic, though rich inner fantasy life could also relate to Investigative intellectual curiosity.

items.text: I tend to see the world differently from most people around me.
items.rationale: Perceiving oneself as having a unique perspective is Artistic, but could also reflect general nonconformity not specific to creative interests.

items.text: I enjoy designing creative solutions to complex problems.
items.rationale: The creative design element is Artistic, but the focus on complex problem-solving overlaps substantially with the Investigative type.

items.text: I prefer work where I follow clear procedures and established guidelines.
items.rationale: Preference for clear procedures and guidelines is a defining feature of the Conventional type.

items.text: I find satisfaction in organizing files, data, and records so everything is in its proper place.
items.rationale: Enjoyment of organizing and maintaining orderly systems is a core Conventional behavior.

items.text: I am detail-oriented and take pride in producing error-free work.
items.rationale: Attention to detail and accuracy are central Conventional traits.

items.text: I enjoy working with spreadsheets, databases, and accounting software.
items.rationale: Preference for structured data tools directly reflects Conventional interests.

items.text: I like knowing exactly what is expected of me at work each day.
items.rationale: Desire for predictability and clear expectations is a hallmark of the Conventional orientation.

items.text: People can count on me to keep accurate records and meet every deadline.
items.rationale: Third-person reliability in record-keeping and deadlines captures Conventional dependability.

items.text: I would enjoy a career in bookkeeping, auditing, or office administration.
items.rationale: Direct endorsement of prototypical Conventional occupations.

items.text: I feel uncomfortable when tasks are ambiguous and there is no standard way to complete them.
items.rationale: Discomfort with ambiguity and preference for standardization are core Conventional characteristics.

items.text: I am good at proofreading documents and catching small mistakes others miss.
items.rationale: Skill and enjoyment in meticulous checking tasks reflects Conventional strengths.

items.text: I like to plan my day carefully and follow a consistent routine.
items.rationale: Preference for planning and routine is strongly associated with the Conventional type.

items.text: I believe that rules and regulations exist for good reasons and should be followed.
items.rationale: Respect for rules and institutional structure is a defining Conventional value.

items.text: I get a sense of accomplishment from completing repetitive tasks efficiently and correctly.
items.rationale: Finding satisfaction in repetitive, accurate task completion is distinctly Conventional.

items.text: I prefer a stable, well-structured work environment over one that is constantly changing.
items.rationale: Preference for stability is Conventional, though Realistic types may also value structured environments.

items.text: I am the person in my friend group who keeps track of plans, reservations, and logistics.
items.rationale: Organizational behavior in social contexts is Conventional, though it could also reflect Social helpfulness.

items.text: I enjoy managing budgets and making sure financial records are balanced and up to date.
items.rationale: Budget management is Conventional, but the managerial and resource-allocation aspect can overlap with Enterprising interests.

items.text: I enjoy persuading others to see things my way and rallying people around a shared goal.
items.rationale: Persuasion and motivating others toward goals are core Enterprising behaviors.

items.text: I am naturally competitive and thrive in environments where I can get ahead.
items.rationale: Competitiveness and ambition are defining Enterprising traits.

items.text: I would love to start my own business and be my own boss.
items.rationale: Entrepreneurial aspiration and desire for autonomy through leadership are prototypically Enterprising.

items.text: I am energized by negotiating deals and closing sales.
items.rationale: Enjoyment of negotiation and sales activities directly reflects Enterprising interests.

items.text: People often look to me to take charge when a group needs direction.
items.rationale: Being seen as a natural leader is a strong third-person indicator of the Enterprising type.

items.text: I am drawn to careers in management, marketing, or politics.
items.rationale: Direct endorsement of prototypical Enterprising occupations.

items.text: I enjoy taking calculated risks if there is a chance for a big payoff.
items.rationale: Risk-taking for potential reward is a hallmark Enterprising behavior.

items.text: I am good at spotting opportunities that others overlook.
items.rationale: Opportunity recognition is a key Enterprising cognitive style.

items.text: I measure my success largely by my achievements, status, and influence.
items.rationale: Valuing status, achievement, and influence are core Enterprising motivations.

items.text: I find it exciting to pitch new ideas to investors or decision-makers.
items.rationale: Pitching and selling ideas reflects the persuasive, initiative-taking nature of the Enterprising type.

items.text: I prefer to lead a project rather than be a team member following someone else's plan.
items.rationale: Preference for leadership over followership is a strong Enterprising indicator.

items.text: I am comfortable making high-stakes decisions under pressure.
items.rationale: Comfort with high-pressure decision-making reflects Enterprising confidence and decisiveness.

items.text: I enjoy networking and building professional relationships that could benefit my career.
items.rationale: Strategic networking is Enterprising, though the interpersonal element could partially overlap with Social interests.

items.text: I like motivating a team and helping each person perform at their best.
items.rationale: Motivating teams is Enterprising leadership, but the helping and developmental focus introduces some Social overlap.

items.text: I enjoy organizing community fundraising events and rallying volunteers for a cause.
items.rationale: Organizing and rallying people is Enterprising, but the prosocial, community-oriented focus overlaps with the Social type.

items.text: I love diving deep into a complex problem and not stopping until I understand it fully.
items.rationale: Persistent, deep analytical engagement with complex problems is a core Investigative behavior.

items.text: I enjoy reading scientific journals and staying current with the latest research.
items.rationale: Active engagement with scientific literature directly reflects Investigative interests.

items.text: I would rather analyze data than manage people.
items.rationale: Preference for analytical work over interpersonal management clearly distinguishes Investigative from Enterprising and Social types.

items.text: I am fascinated by how things work at a fundamental level—whether it's the human body, the universe, or a computer algorithm.
items.rationale: Curiosity about fundamental mechanisms across domains is a hallmark of the Investigative type.

items.text: People describe me as analytical, curious, and intellectually driven.
items.rationale: Third-person description capturing the core Investigative traits of analytical thinking and intellectual curiosity.

items.text: I would enjoy a career as a research scientist, mathematician, or data analyst.
items.rationale: Direct endorsement of prototypical Investigative occupations.

items.text: I prefer to observe and study a situation carefully before taking action.
items.rationale: Preference for observation and analysis before action is a defining Investigative approach.

items.text: I enjoy designing experiments or studies to test a hypothesis.
items.rationale: Experimental design and hypothesis testing are core Investigative activities.

items.text: I find abstract theories and conceptual frameworks more interesting than practical applications.
items.rationale: Preference for abstract theory over practical application is a strong Investigative indicator.

items.text: I can spend hours researching a topic just because I'm curious, even if it has no practical use.
items.rationale: Intrinsically motivated intellectual exploration is a defining Investigative behavior.

items.text: I am skeptical of claims that aren't backed by solid evidence.
items.rationale: Evidence-based skepticism reflects the critical, rational thinking style of the Investigative type.

items.text: I enjoy solving puzzles, brain teasers, and logic problems in my spare time.
items.rationale: Recreational engagement with intellectual challenges is a behavioral marker of Investigative interests.

items.text: I like working independently on intellectual tasks rather than collaborating in groups.
items.rationale: Preference for independent intellectual work is Investigative, though the solitary preference could also characterize Realistic types.

items.text: I enjoy learning new programming languages and figuring out how to make software work better.
items.rationale: Programming involves analytical problem-solving (Investigative), but the applied technical skill element introduces some Realistic overlap.

items.text: I enjoy troubleshooting technical systems by systematically testing each component until I find the fault.
items.rationale: Systematic diagnostic reasoning is Investigative, but hands-on troubleshooting of technical systems overlaps with the Realistic type.

items.text: I enjoy working with my hands to build, fix, or assemble things.
items.rationale: Hands-on building and fixing activities are the most prototypical Realistic behaviors.

items.text: I would rather be outdoors doing physical work than sitting at a desk all day.
items.rationale: Preference for outdoor, physical work over sedentary office work is a core Realistic orientation.

items.text: I find it satisfying to use tools and machinery to complete a tangible project.
items.rationale: Satisfaction from tool use and tangible outcomes is a defining Realistic characteristic.

items.text: I am good at understanding how mechanical systems and equipment work.
items.rationale: Mechanical comprehension and aptitude are core Realistic competencies.

items.text: I would enjoy a career as an electrician, mechanic, carpenter, or engineer.
items.rationale: Direct endorsement of prototypical Realistic occupations.

items.text: I prefer practical, concrete tasks over abstract or theoretical ones.
items.rationale: Preference for concrete over abstract work clearly distinguishes Realistic from Investigative and Artistic types.

items.text: I like being physically active during my workday rather than sitting still.
items.rationale: Preference for physical activity during work is a strong Realistic indicator.

items.text: I enjoy tinkering with engines, electronics, or other mechanical devices in my free time.
items.rationale: Recreational tinkering with mechanical and electronic devices is a behavioral hallmark of the Realistic type.

items.text: I take pride in being able to repair things around the house without calling a professional.
items.rationale: Self-reliance in practical repair tasks reflects Realistic competence and values.

items.text: I am most comfortable in work environments where I can see the direct, physical results of my effort.
items.rationale: Valuing tangible, visible outcomes of physical effort is a core Realistic motivation.

items.text: I enjoy activities like woodworking, welding, gardening, or restoring old vehicles.
items.rationale: Engagement with hands-on craft and restoration activities is prototypically Realistic.

items.text: I don't mind getting dirty or sweaty if it means I'm getting real work done.
items.rationale: Willingness to engage in physically demanding, messy work is a strong Realistic indicator.

items.text: I like learning new practical skills, such as how to operate different types of equipment.
items.rationale: Learning practical skills is Realistic, though the learning motivation could partially overlap with Investigative curiosity.

items.text: I prefer to communicate through actions and results rather than lengthy discussions.
items.rationale: Action-oriented communication style is Realistic, though it could also reflect low Social interest more broadly.

items.text: I enjoy building detailed scale models or crafting intricate handmade objects.
items.rationale: Hands-on crafting is Realistic, but the emphasis on detail and aesthetic craftsmanship introduces overlap with the Artistic type.

items.text: I find deep fulfillment in helping others work through their personal problems.
items.rationale: Deriving fulfillment from helping others with personal issues is a core Social motivation.

items.text: I am naturally empathetic and can easily sense how others are feeling.
items.rationale: Empathy and emotional attunement are defining Social traits.

items.text: I would enjoy a career as a teacher, counselor, social worker, or nurse.
items.rationale: Direct endorsement of prototypical Social occupations.

items.text: I believe my greatest strength is my ability to connect with people and make them feel understood.
items.rationale: Valuing interpersonal connection and understanding as a core strength is distinctly Social.

items.text: I am happiest when I know my work is making a positive difference in someone's life.
items.rationale: Deriving happiness from prosocial impact is a central Social value.

items.text: I enjoy mentoring younger colleagues and helping them develop their skills.
items.rationale: Mentoring and developmental support are prototypical Social behaviors.

items.text: I am patient and willing to explain things multiple times until someone truly understands.
items.rationale: Patience in teaching and communication reflects the nurturing, educational orientation of the Social type.

items.text: I gravitate toward volunteer work and community service in my free time.
items.rationale: Voluntary prosocial engagement is a strong behavioral indicator of Social interests.

items.text: I prefer working closely with people rather than working alone with data or machines.
items.rationale: Preference for interpersonal work over solitary or technical work clearly distinguishes the Social type.

items.text: I am a good listener and people often come to me for advice or emotional support.
items.rationale: Being sought out as a listener and advisor is a third-person behavioral marker of the Social type.

items.text: I care more about whether my work helps people than whether it pays well.
items.rationale: Prioritizing prosocial impact over financial reward is a defining Social value orientation.

items.text: I feel energized after spending time helping a group of people learn something new.
items.rationale: Gaining energy from teaching and group facilitation is a strong Social indicator.

items.text: I enjoy facilitating group discussions and making sure everyone's voice is heard.
items.rationale: Group facilitation is Social, but the organizational and leadership element could partially overlap with Enterprising.

items.text: I am interested in understanding why people behave the way they do.
items.rationale: Interest in human behavior is Social, but the analytical, understanding-focused framing introduces some Investigative overlap.

items.text: I enjoy coaching a sports team because I love developing each player's potential and building team spirit.
items.rationale: Developing others is Social, but coaching also involves the physical, hands-on activity orientation of the Realistic type.
